awd_titl_txt: Nanoscale investigations of water-solid interfaces for filtration applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: 1604504, PI: Riedo, E.
Title: Nanoscale investigations of water-solid interfaces for filtration applications  
 
Widely available clean water is one of the greatest current and future global challenges. Water is essential for life and it is a key-factor in many technological and biological processes. This research, which focuses on interfacial/confined water flow, will have a direct impact not only in separation and water filtration processes but also in understanding lubrication processes, membrane hydration in fuel cells, and the molecular interaction of water with cell membranes and in biological pores. This project will produce fundamental understanding of the nanoscale physics and chemistry of the interface between aqueous solutions and solid surfaces for the purpose of developing new desalinization systems based on nanoporous membranes. A critical knowledge gap in using nanoscale materials, is the understanding of the solid-liquid interactions at the nanoscale, which differ from those of the bulk phase. New models of fluid transport at the nanoscale are expected to emerge from this research. The broader impacts of this project include educational activities, which will take place at the Advanced Science Research Center (ASRC), which is a brand new multi-disciplinary center in NYC. Collaborations between the ASRC, CUNY colleges, and Columbia University are at the core of this center, whose goal is to support scholarship and student learning at multiple levels.
 
Membranes and porous materials with pore size in the sub-nanometer scale are important for separation processes, such as water desalination. The project's long-term goal is to generate novel nanoporous membranes based on layered materials such as those based on graphene oxide, graphene, boron nitride, and molybdenum disulfide. The project will combine the use of advanced scanning probe microscopy methods of model aqueous solutions and model nanoporous membranes with molecular dynamics computer simulations to determine how the properties of aqueous solutions, e.g. ion concentration, ion specificity, presence of co-solvents and other solutes,  and the complexity of the interfacial surface, e.g. degree of confinement, functional groups, chemistry, heterogeneity, presence of electric fields, influence the structure, ions arrangement, viscosity, viscoelasticity, slip, electro-kinetics, and flow of water/ions solutions at solid/liquid interfaces. All this information will help inform the design of desalination membranes with improved permeability and improved understanding of the impact of membrane surface chemistry and also of adjoining solution chemistry and their rheological properties.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This proposal aimed at gaining a fundamental understanding of the nanoscale physics and chemistry of the interface between aqueous solutions and complex solid surfaces. In particular, we combined advanced experimental surface science and scanning probe microscopy methods with computer simulations to address the interface between water and two-dimensional atomic thick materials, such as graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides, as well as the interface between water solutions and ad-hoc chemically nanopatterned surfaces. Applications range from water filtering membranes to biological tissue engineering.

Broader Impact: Part of NYU and CUNY mission is to broaden participation in the STEM areas through research. Towards this aim, the participants of this grant have partnered with NYU and CUNY programs to engage undergraduate and graduate students in research projects on the physics and chemistry of nanoscale solid-liquid interfaces. Furthermore, at the NYU Tandon School of Engineering the PI has led the organization of the prestigious Tandon Faculty First Look Fellowship program, geared towards young talented scholars all over the US, in particular from underrepresented communities in STEM. Candidates should be nearing completion of their Ph.D. or be in a post-doctoral position and interested in a career in academia. Fellows have the opportunity to spend one day at NYU to present and receive feedback on their ongoing research, engage with NYU faculty from a range of engineering disciplines, and participate in workshops designed to help them advance their careers. Finally, within this NSF grant a new course on "Nanoscale Characterization of Nanomaterials" has been developed for both graduate and undergraduate students.

Key outcomes of this project include:

 (1) Characterization of the phase behavior of water confined at the nanoscale between two graphene sheets, demonstrating a remarkably complex phase diagram of water confined at the nanoscale between graphene surfaces. Our simulations have predicted the presence of a "square ice" and have determined the effect of working conditions (temperature and pressure) on the effective forces between the graphene plates. These results will have an impact in designing water membranes based on graphene layers. 

(2) Fabrication by thermal scanning probe lithography (tSPL) of sub-10 nm chemical patterns of charged/hydrophilic chemical groups, and developing a comparative study of water-mediated interactions between hydrophilic and hydrophobic nanoscale surfaces. Furthermore, tSPL has been exploited to reproduce at the nanoscale, in a polymer canvas, the complexity of biological tissues, with potential for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications.

(3) Study of water/surface interactions in the case of polycrystalline two-dimensional (2D) materials. A large effort is underway to investigate the properties of 2D materials for their potential to become building blocks in a variety of applications, including filtration membranes. Our experiments have allowed to understand the relationship between water molecules adsorption, friction, adhesion, electric charges and defects in polycrystalline piezoelectric 2D materials, which is of key importance for their assembly and use in nano-electro-mechanical and nanofluidic systems. In particular, we demonstrated a new oscillatory behavior of nanoscopic friction and adhesion in continuous polycrystalline MoS2 films for odd and even number of atomic layers.
